2052. Tucker, Susan T. (Mrs. George)
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. George L. Tucker
Present Address: Rosetown, Sask. (Bay 190)
Pioneer Address: Crack, Sask.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

[Handwritten note:]
Eastside after our 1914 war.
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 10

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 5 bachelor's homes

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Visited & had dinner directly opposite three different neighbors.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sunday

4. Were you often invited to other houses, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Invited only when able to find time which was seldom. We waited for special occasion.

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Departed in morning, left in afternoon - before dark.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Most pioneers used term "pot luck."

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? No milk, morning or afternoon snack - strictly 5 meal a day.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The whole family visited.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, but not until 1911 - or thereabouts.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. Earlier pioneers usually did things on their own.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. None - too late for such foolishness. Too tired to get up nights. Went to bed with the sun & got up with the sun.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. After first Great War - 1914 - on.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

Sunday card playing was taboo. Card games were associated by a few with gambling but became so popular extensive after the 1914 war. Not before.
